question: In adults with chronic primary insomnia, does cognitive behavioral therapy improve sleep efficiency and sleep quality compared with hypnotic medication or placebo over short- and long-term follow-up? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Participants receiving CBT improved their sleep efficiency from 81.4% at pretreatment to 90.1% at 6-month follow-up compared with a decrease from 82.3% to 81.9% in the zopiclone group.
content.source_2: In a multicenter trial, interventions based on CBT did not outperform zopiclone treatment in either short- or long-term management of insomnia in older adults.
content.source_3: Participants in the CBT group spent much more time in slow-wave sleep (stages 3 and 4) compared with those in other groups, and spent less time awake during the night.
content.source_4: RESULTS CBT failed to improve outcomes relative to zopiclone on 3 out of 4 pre-specified measures, with benefits limited to a single subjective index.
